concept: P versus NP Problem - Official Clay Millennium Problem Description
abstract: The P vs NP problem asks whether every problem whose solution can be quickly verified can also be quickly solved. It was first presented by Stephen Cook in 1971 in his seminal paper 'The Complexity of Theorem-Proving Procedures'. This problem remains unresolved and is one of the seven Millennium Prize Problems.
Introduces the concept of NP-completeness and establishes SAT as NP-complete. Provides the foundational link between search problems and computational complexity.
Examines how NP-complete problems might relate to physical processes, such as quantum mechanics and statistical physics. Argues that NP-completeness likely transcends specific models of computation.
Discusses the concept of relativization, showing that both P=NP and P≠NP can be true relative to different oracles, implying that new techniques beyond relativization are needed.

Defines 'natural proofs' and shows that a broad class of proof techniques are unlikely to resolve P vs NP if strong pseudorandom generators exist. Introduces a major barrier to traditional techniques.

concept: Algebrization: A New Barrier in Complexity Theory
abstract: Introduces 'algebrization', a generalization of relativization, and shows that it too cannot settle P vs NP. Suggests that radically new techniques are required.

Proposes using algebraic geometry and representation theory to attack complexity problems like P vs NP. Introduces the GCT program, leveraging deep mathematics beyond traditional combinatorial methods.

concept: Proof Complexity and the P vs NP Problem
abstract: Reviews how proof complexity can contribute to resolving P vs NP. Focuses on lower bounds for proof systems and their implications for circuit lower bounds.
Explains advances in SAT solvers and how practical solving often outpaces worst-case complexity predictions. Discusses implications for understanding NP-completeness in practice.

concept: Quantum Supremacy and the Complexity of Random Circuit Sampling
abstract: Proposes random circuit sampling as a method to demonstrate quantum computational supremacy. Discusses connections to complexity-theoretic hardness assumptions.
Applies methods from statistical mechanics to analyze the structure of NP-hard optimization problems, particularly satisfiability problems.
Explores how hardness amplification techniques relate to derandomization and implications for circuit complexity.

concept: P, NP, and the Polynomial Hierarchy
abstract: Provides an approachable introduction to the polynomial hierarchy and how it relates to P vs NP.

concept: On Problems as Hard as SAT
abstract: Discusses problems that are provably as hard as SAT under various reductions, and implications for average-case complexity.
Reviews recent work on the satisfiability threshold conjecture for random k-SAT formulas and its links to phase transitions in computational hardness.

concept: Survey on Lower Bounds in Proof Complexity
abstract: Surveys known lower bounds in proof complexity and discusses their relevance to major complexity-theoretic questions.
Investigates hardness assumptions from the perspective of learnability and pseudo-randomness, with implications for P vs NP.
